A gastrectomy does not directly impact Vitamin A absorption, so supplementation is not typically necessary unless there is another underlying deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 due to the loss of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of this vitamin

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance
Creatinine is equal to inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Creatinine clearance? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance

 

  • Creatinine clearance is often used as a measure of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) but it is important to note that it slightly overestimates GFR. This overestimation is because creatinine is not only filtered by the glomerulus but also secreted in small amounts by the renal tubules. Therefore, creatinine clearance is typically greater than inulin clearance.
  • Inulin clearance, on the other hand, is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR. Inulin is a polysaccharide that is freely filtered by the kidneys but neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Thus, it provides an accurate measure of the filtration capacity of the kidneys.

 

Clinical Relevance

 

  • Inulin clearance is an accurate measure but is seldom used in clinical practice due to the complexity and cost of the procedure.
  • Creatinine clearance, despite its limitations, is commonly used because it is simpler and cheaper to measure. It requires only serum and urine creatinine levels, making it practical for routine medical evaluations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance: Incorrect because creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR due to additional renal tubular secretion.

 

Option C. Creatinine clearance is equal to inulin clearance: Incorrect because the secretion of creatinine leads to higher clearance values compared to inulin.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as option B correctly describes the relationship between creatinine and inulin clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine clearance is commonly used to estimate GFR but it is greater than inulin clearance due to slight secretion of creatinine by the renal tubules. In contrast, inulin clearance, being neither secreted nor reabsorbed, provides a more accurate measurement of renal filtration function.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

APML is a leukemia with excellent prognosis managed with Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by infiltrates, pleural effusion after treatment and improves with Dexamethasone. Used Intrathecally in children for AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin is a cardiotoxic drug used in Hodgkin, CA breast, thyroid.

 

Option D. Methotrexate is not recommended in APML treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs.

 

Reference -Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c wave

 

The jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform consists of multiple waves that correspond to different phases of the cardiac cycle.

 

The "c" wave corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, causing a brief increase in pressure in the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "a" wave corresponds to the atrial contraction, which occurs during the late ventricular filling phase of the cardiac cycle. This is the period before the closure of the mitral/ tricuspid valve. The "a" wave is caused by the contraction of the atrium, leading to a brief increase in right atrial pressure.

 

Option C. The "x" descent corresponds to the returning of the tricuspid valve to its normal position during ventricular contraction (i.e. ejection) and atrial relaxation.

 

Option D. The "y" descent corresponds to the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle during ventricular diastole.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "c" wave of the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, reflecting the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium as the right ventricle begins to contract.

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

questions.text: Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in metabolism, growth, and development. They exert their effects through specific receptor types in target cells. Through which type of receptor does thyroid hormone primarily act?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nuclear receptors

 

Thyroid hormones act via nuclear receptors. These receptors, when bound by thyroid hormones, regulate the transcription of specific genes, influencing various physiological processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic receptors: Incorrect. While some steroid hormones act via cytoplasmic receptors, thyroid hormones primarily function through receptors located in the nucleus.

 

Option B. Tyrosine kinase receptors: Incorrect. Tyrosine kinase receptors are typically associated with growth factors and cytokines, not thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormones do not activate tyrosine kinase pathways directly.

 

Option D. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR): Incorrect. GPCRs are a large family of cell surface receptors that respond to a variety of external signals, but thyroid hormones do not act through these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones primarily exert their effects through nuclear receptors, influencing gene transcription and various physiological processes.

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimum volume

 

If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume. This is due to the inherent elastic properties of the lung tissue, which tend to make the lungs contract inward when not counteracted by the outward elastic recoil of the chest wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zero: Incorrect. The lung cannot have zero volume due to the presence of air in the alveoli and residual airways even at its minimal state.

 

Option C. Functional residual capacity: Incorrect. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration, which includes the balance between the inward recoil of the lungs and the outward recoil of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. The minimum volume after elastic recoil without the chest wall support would be less than the residual volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it would collapse to its minimum volume due to the lung's inherent elastic properties.

questions.text: Central venules have which type of cells in the center? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) RBCs


The central venules are part of the vascular system where blood flow dynamics play a crucial role in cell distribution. The concept of parabolic flow describes how blood components are distributed within the vessel. In this flow pattern, the velocity of the blood is highest at the center of the vessel and decreases towards the periphery.

 

  • RBCs (Red Blood Cells): Due to their biconcave shape and flexibility, RBCs tend to move towards the center of the vessel where the flow velocity is highest. This central position allows them to travel efficiently through the bloodstream without being impeded by the endothelial cells lining the vessel walls.
  • WBCs (White Blood Cells): These cells, which include lymphocytes, neutrophils, and macrophages, are larger and less flexible compared to RBCs. As a result, they are often found closer to the vessel walls where the flow velocity is lower. This positioning is also influenced by the process of margination, where WBCs move towards and interact with the endothelial cells, particularly during inflammation.
  • Platelets: Although smaller than RBCs, platelets have an irregular shape and tend to get trapped in the spaces between endothelial cells, preventing them from flowing freely in the center of the vessel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocytes and B. Neutrophils:  Types of WBC, tend to be located near the vessel walls due to their larger size and the process of margination.

 

Option C. Macrophages: These are larger WBCs involved in immune responses and are usually found in the periphery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In central venules, RBCs are found in the center due to their shape, flexibility, and the dynamics of parabolic flow.

questions.text: Calcium binds to which one of the following proteins in smooth muscle contraction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calmodulin

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium plays a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction, similar to its role in skeletal muscle cells. However, the proteins that interact with calcium to start the contraction process are different in these two muscle types.

 

In skeletal muscle cells, calcium binds to troponin, which is part of the troponin-tropomyosin complex that regulates the interaction of actin and myosin, leading to muscle contraction. However, in smooth muscle cells, the contraction mechanism does not involve troponin.

 

In smooth muscle, when calcium ions enter the cell, they bind to a protein called calmodulin. This calcium-calmodulin complex then activates an enzyme called myosin light chain kinase (MLCK). Activated MLCK phosphorylates the myosin light chains, leading to conformational changes in myosin heads that allow them to interact with actin filaments, thereby causing muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a structural protein that forms filaments and interacts with myosin during muscle contraction. However, calcium does not bind directly to actin in smooth muscle to initiate contraction.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is a regulatory protein associated with actin filaments, but in smooth muscle, it does not play the same role in calcium binding as it does in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. Troponin: Troponin is the protein to which calcium binds in skeletal muscle to initiate contraction. However, troponin is absent in smooth muscle, so it cannot be the correct answer for smooth muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In smooth muscle cells, calcium binds to calmodulin to initiate muscle contraction, unlike in skeletal muscle where calcium binds to troponin.

choices.text: Increased production of heat by liver

questions.text: Which physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperature while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating and vasodilation in skin

 

When a person exercises vigorously, especially in high temperatures, the body needs to maintain its internal temperature within a safe range. During exercise, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to muscle contractions and relaxations. This process generates heat as a byproduct. To prevent overheating, the body employs two key mechanisms: sweating and vasodilation.

 

  • Sweating: Sweat glands produce sweat, which is released onto the skin surface. As the sweat evaporates, it helps cool the body down.
  • Vasodilation: Blood vessels in the skin widen (dilate), increasing blood flow to the skin. This allows more heat to be transferred from the body core to the skin, where it can be dissipated into the environment.

 

These processes help in losing excess heat and maintaining a stable internal body temperature during vigorous exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shivering and vasoconstriction in skin: These responses occur in cold environments to conserve heat. Shivering generates heat through muscle activity, and vasoconstriction reduces blood flow to the skin to minimize heat loss. These mechanisms are not activated in high temperatures.

 

Option C. Increased production of heat by liver: Although the liver does produce some heat, the question specifically asks for the physiological responses to high temperature and exercise. The primary responses are mechanisms to lose heat, not produce more.

 

Option D. Decreased heart rate: During vigorous exercise, the heart rate typically increases, not decreases, to supply muscles with more oxygen and nutrients. This response is part of the body's overall effort to support increased physical activity and manage heat stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During vigorous exercise in high temperatures, the body primarily responds by increasing sweating and vasodilation to dissipate heat and maintain a stable internal body temperature

questions.text: The fast electrical rhythm in gastrointestinal smooth muscle is primarily generated by: [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smooth muscle cells

 

Smooth muscle cells generate fast electrical rhythm (spike potentials) in GI tract. These spike potentials:

  • Are triggered by but distinct from slow waves
  • Directly cause muscle contraction
  • Have amplitude of 60-70 mV
  • Occur when slow wave depolarization reaches threshold

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myenteric neurons: Incorrect. These modulate GI motility but don't generate spike potentials.

 

Option C. Interstitial cells of Cajal: Incorrect. Generate slow waves but not spike potentials.

 

Option D. Migrating motor complex: Incorrect. This is a motility pattern, not a cell type capable of generating electrical activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the distinction between slow waves (generated by ICCs) and spike potentials (generated by smooth muscle cells) in GI motility.

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.
